addNextI

public static <T> void addNextI(java.util.Collection<T> collection,
                                T nextElement,
                                java.lang.String indexPropertyName)
Adds the next element in a collection. The meaning of next is that the type defined by T has an indexProperty. This property is specified by the parameter indexPropertyName. This property can be only Integer. Specifying a property that is not of type Integer or Long, will result in a RuntimeException. This method will find the max value of the index property in the collection and will modify the next element by setting to it the index property to max + 1.
This method will not fill any gap in the values of the index property. The collection could have gaps, namely it could have elements with values 1, 2, 3, 5 in the index property. This method will add the next element which is 6 and 4 will remain a gap.
If collection is empty, then the new element will get 1 as value of the index property.
If the nextElement already has a value on the index property that is greater than the maximum index in the array, then it will keep this value. In the latter case, it is possible to introduce new gaps in the indexes of the elements in the collection.
The nextElement is modified, before being added to the collection. Even if the index property affects the element's hashcode, it is guaranteed that the hashcode will change before adding the element to the collection.

Type Parameters:
T - Type of elements.
Parameters:
collection - Collection in which the next element is being added.
nextElement - Next element that will be added in the collection.
indexPropertyName - Name of the property that defines the index.

addNextL

public static <T> void addNextL(java.util.Collection<T> collection,
                                T nextElement,
                                java.lang.String indexPropertyName)
Adds the next element in a collection. This is exactly the same method as addNextI(collection, t, string) with the difference that it is intended for an index property of type Long.

Type Parameters:
T - Type of elements.
Parameters:
collection - Collection in which the next element is being added.
nextElement - Next element that will be added in the collection.
indexPropertyName - Name of the property that defines the index.
See Also:
addNextI(Collection, Object, String)

toMap

public static <K,V> java.util.Map<K,V> toMap(java.util.Collection<V> collection,
                                             java.lang.String property,
                                             java.lang.Class<V> entityType)
Puts the elements of a collection in a map using a specified property of the elements as key.

Type Parameters:
V - Type of elements in the collection. The type defined be .
K - Type of property used as key.
Parameters:
collection - Collection with the elements.
property - Name of the property that will be used as key.
entityType - Declaration class of elements in the collection.
Returns:
Returns a map that maps all elements of the collection to the value of the specified property.
Throws:
java.lang.NullPointerException - If any of the collection's elements has the specified property null.
java.lang.RuntimeException - If the class does not have a property with the specified name.

sort

public static <P,T extends P> java.util.List<T> sort(java.util.Collection<T> collection,
                                                     java.lang.Class<P> clazz,
                                                     java.lang.String property1,
                                                     java.lang.String property2)
Sorts a collection based on two properties of its elements. The returned collection is first sorted with property1 and then with property2. This means that the result is sorted by property1 and that each sub-collection that has a specific value for property1 is sorted by property2.

Type Parameters:
P - type of elements in the collection.
T - type of elements in the collection.
Parameters:
collection - Collection to sort.
clazz - Class of the elements in the collection.
property1 - The first property to sort with. This can't be a nested property.
property2 - The second property to sort with. This can't be a nested property.
Returns:
Sorted List.

countByProperty

public static <S,T extends S> int countByProperty(java.lang.String property,
                                                  java.lang.Object value,
                                                  java.util.Collection<T> collection,
                                                  java.lang.Class<S> type)
Gets the count of items in the specified collection that have the specified property equal to the specified value.

Type Parameters:
S - Type of objects in the collection.
T - Class to evaluate the property with. Must be a super-type of T.
Parameters:
property - Name of property being used as selection criterion.
value - Value of selection criterion. It can be null.
collection - Collection of objects.
type - Type of objects in the collection.
Returns:
Returns the count of items in the specified collection that have the specified property equal to the specified value.
